class.name: Elementalist (Tanares)
class.proficiency: Intelligence, Wisdom, Arcana, History, Insight, Nature, Perception, Persuasion, Religion

trait.name: Elementalist
trait.text:
In a serene garden, a wise elementalist master prepares tea for its disciples with the utmost precision, their every movement harmoniously aligned with the elements. As the tea leaves dance in the boiling water, the disciples sense a deep connection to the elements, feeling the master's power coursing through their veins. When confronted by ruthless bandits, a soulborn elementalist commands the elements with a flick of their wrist, unleashing an icy beam of pure energy that encases half of the bandits in a frozen tomb while the rest flee in terror. Against a monstrous beast, an elf elementalist stands resolute, igniting their weapons and those of their allies with blazing magic. Confidence burns within them as they prepare for an epic battle, ready to vanquish the darkness with the raw power of the elements. Elementalists are versatile and wise spellcasters who serve as advisors, sages, spiritual guides, and teachers. According to prophecies, they hold the power to stop Gullog and his undead armies. Born from an ancestral elven tradition, elementalists stand as a distinct group of spellcasters. Their mastery diverges from conventional arcane practices, delving into the harmonization of elements, energy flow, meditation, and spiritual enlightenment. These wise practitioners dedicate their lives to attuning with one of the four elements, each of which grants distinctive abilities and purpose. Fire elementalists command martial prowess and emotional control, earth elementalists foster unwavering resilience and deep moral compass, air elementalists exhibit cunning, guile, and grace of movement, while the scarce water elementalists practice healing arts, nurturing both body and soul, and advocating temperance and non-attachment. Despite mastering one element, elementalists can manipulate the other two elements that do not directly conflict with their chosen one, enabling combinations of elements to cast spells of magma, plant, lightning, and spiritual magic, and augmenting their vast repertoire. The elementalist's path is a lifelong odyssey built upon the master-disciple relationship. With unwavering commitment, the disciple studies, contemplates, and serves under their master, acquiring elemental wisdom and proper conduct. Years of labor and ordinary tasks precede the true awakening to the powers of Elementalism, as masters cautiously evaluate their disciples' character before bestowing such knowledge. This bond endures for life, underpinned by duty, respect, and honor. Disciples must venerate and assist their masters throughout their lives, undertaking tasks as required and ensuring their actions never tarnish their master's name. Concurrently, masters are obligated to impart wisdom, safeguard their disciples, and foster their spiritual growth, with any abuse constituting great dishonor. Elementalists regard their fellow practitioners as kin, despite differing principles and views among schools devoted to various elements. They engage in fervent debates, never overstepping the bounds of theological, philosophical, and metaphysical discourse. Their relationships with other magic users are intricate, often considering wizards and sorcerers untrustworthy due to their immense powers without requisite wisdom and moral enlightenment. However, those displaying tempered conduct and good character are highly esteemed. Clerics earn respect for their devotion and moral code, but their potential fanaticism incites wariness, whereas druids are perceived as kindred spirits, embracing a more primal yet venerable approach to wisdom. In the world of Tanares, an ominous threat looms as the immortal kemet leader, Gullog, seeks to conquer and turn all into icy death. Elementalists are at the heart of a prophecy that may provide salvation, seeing themselves as responsible for restoring the goddess Bás to her pacifist ways and ending Gullog's tyranny. Beyond the prophecy, elementalists serve as spiritual guides, royal advisors, and guardians of elemental energies. Guided by the teachings of venerable masters and their respected schools and enclaves, elementalists confront Tanares' challenges with the perspective of ancient wisdom.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 78 (Homebrew)

trait.name: History of Elementalism
trait.text: Within the time-worn tomes of Tanares, the tale of the elven kin is woven in intricate prose. Once thriving in a realm of unmatched beauty, the elves had their world shattered by the apocalyptic fury of their own goddess, Bás. Spurred by the heinous deeds of the malefic Ungods, her rage laid waste to the once-pristine elven lands. Amidst the frozen ruins, the remnants of the elves sought sanctuary in Tanares, guided by the wisdom of their remaining divine trinity. In their newfound haven, the divine triad endowed the elven people with the mystical knowledge of Elementalism, an art that would serve as their salvation and guide their path in the new world. Entwined within this sacred gift, a prophecy unfurled, foretelling the inexorable return of the vengeful Bás and the darkness she would bring upon Tanares. As the elves' prowess in Elementalism blossomed, they clung steadfastly to the hallowed teachings, safeguarding the ancestral secrets within their sanctified enclaves and revered schools. Their vigilance endured, ever-alert for the encroaching shadow of Bás's dreaded return. As the Evolutionist Church's hold on arcane magic intensified, their ranks infiltrated by Ungod cultists, Elementalism arose as a free and unshackled alternative. The Ungods took little notice of the elementalists, leaving them to hone their craft in peace while manipulating the persecution of wizards and sorcerers. Thus, the elves disseminated their knowledge among diverse species, nurturing a thriving community of elementalists across Tanares. Over the ages, water elementalism, once an esteemed elven tradition, dwindled as the winter elves forsook it in pursuit of dark prophecies that transformed them into the kemet people. The remaining elemental arts thrived, providing a substitute for arcane magic. New institutions were founded, as practitioners plumbed the depths of ancient texts, meditated, and performed rites to fortify their bonds with the elements. Their wisdom, echoing the ancient philosophies, became a coveted treasure for rulers, strategists, nobles, and merchants alike. In time, their enclaves, schools, and sects evolved into bastions of enlightenment and erudition. During the Kemet Invasion, the Tanares Empire's strength waned considerably. The kemets, under Gullog's command, invaded Tanares to fulfill Golgöggoth's scheme to strip mortals of their emotions, rendering them impervious to Ungod corruption. Though the combined forces of Tanares vanquished Gullog and the kemets, Bás resurfaced, reviving Gullog and forging an alliance with Golgöggoth to transform Tanares into a frozen, undead wasteland akin to the lost elven realm. With the ancient prophecy of Bás's return now unfolding, the elementalists must confront the trials posed by Bás and Gullog. The scarcity of water elementalists has led their enclaves to prioritize training new adepts, for it is believed that masters of all four elements are essential in facing Bás. As they ready themselves for the impending darkness, the timeless wisdom and deep connections of these exceptional spellweavers will forge the fate of Tanares.

trait.name: Elementalism and the Ungods
trait.text: Elementalists, ever vigilant against the malevolent forces of the Ungods, always aware of the fate of the worlds taken by their corruption, dedicate themselves to thwarting these ancient beings and their wicked schemes. Knowing what happened to the elven world, elementalists recognize the price of failure and commit to safeguarding Tanares from a similar fate. Guided by the teachings of venerable masters, elementalists wield the elements to counter the myriad threats posed by the Ungods. They relentlessly confront the hidden servants who sow discord among mortals and battle the penumbral creatures that lurk in the shadows, seeking to breach into the Material Plane. Elementalists tirelessly work to prevent wars and unrest among factions, as they know that such conflicts only serve to empower the Ungods and hasten their nefarious plans. Air elementalists, cunning and acrobatic, infiltrate the hidden networks of the Ungods' servants. They disrupt the corrupt machinations from within, shielding the innocent from the clutches of the Cult of Shadow Wing. Earth elementalists, resolute and steadfast, stand guard over sacred places of power, preventing the Ungods from seizing these elemental energy sources. Fire elementalists, with their martial prowess, ignite the hearts of those who would defy the Ungods, inspiring them to resist the encroaching darkness. Water elementalists, rare and sagacious, offer healing and wisdom to those tainted by the Ungods' influence, cleansing them of corruption. To strengthen their ranks, elementalists endeavor to educate and inspire others in the ways of elementalism. Through rigorous training and the sharing of wisdom, they prepare new generations to battle the forces of the Ungods and avert the apocalyptic doom that befell their world. They instill a sense of duty, honor, and respect, nurturing lifelong bonds between master and disciple. Thus, the lineage of elemental wisdom endures, perpetually growing stronger. Elementalists draw upon the wisdom of their ancestral masters, forging a connection to ancient traditions and spiritual disciplines. Through long seclusions, rigorous study, and intense training, they become dignified forebears, their practices evoking a sense of time-honored tradition and spiritual commitment. They are ever vigilant against the encroachment of the Ungods' influence, striving to preserve the delicate balance of the world.

trait.name: The Return of Bás
trait.text: The elementalists hold the Cuibhle pantheon in the highest regard, venerating the elven gods as the wisest ancestors and elemental masters. Breith, god of spring and earth; Òigridh, goddess of summer and fire; Aibidh, god of autumn and air; and Bás, once the gentle goddess of winter and death, are believed to spin the wheel of life in an eternal dance. Bás, though lost to wrath and vengeance, remains an ancient master of elementalists. Her heart turned cold, and her vision clouded by hatred for the Ungods, so the elementalists do not seek her destruction, but rather her redemption. They liken her to the calm and raging oceans, her actions reflecting the duality of the elemental forces. Her alliance with Gullog and Golgöggoth, the Augur, unveiled chilling plans for an icy wasteland free of life, making the world immune to the Ungods' corruption. Bás's goal is a twisted version of her once noble purpose, and the elementalists are integral in halting her descent. Air elementalists disrupt the freezing winds, earth elementalists stand against the encroaching frost, fire elementalists combat the cold with their passion, and water elementalists, critical to restoring balance, strive to heal and rejuvenate the land, countering Bás's icy grasp. Rumors suggest that the most ancient elves, direct disciples of the gods themselves, have returned from seclusion following Bás's reemergence. They purportedly carry knowledge of three divine artifacts, imbued with the essence of the gods of Summer, Autumn, and Spring, holding the key to swaying Bás and guiding her back to her pacifist ways. These enigmatic masters are believed to be seeking new apprentices to aid in the journey to stop Bás once and for all.

trait.name: The four paths of Elementalism
trait.text: Elementalism The sacred art of Elementalism, passed down through generations of masters, manifests in four distinct paths, each reflecting the unique characteristics, tendencies, and worldviews of the elements themselves. Air Elementalists, known for their free-spirited and perceptive nature, embody the ephemeral essence of the wind. Their training emphasizes cunning, agility, and the art of deception. Through meditation and practice, these elementalists gain the ability to move with the swiftness of the breeze and even defy gravity. They find solace in tea-making, music, and exploration. When not in their schools, they often join merchant or adventuring groups as wandering masters, preferring to avoid conflict, but navigating challenges with cunning and quick thinking when necessary. Earth Elementalists, the bastions of stability and tradition, resonate with the unyielding resilience of stone. Their connection to the earth grants them an unparalleled awareness of its vibrations and mysteries. Often dedicating themselves to matters such as law, architecture, and history, they record the past and present through intricate calligraphy and poetic prose. They may find purpose in bureaucratic positions, state administration, or roles that maintain order, and while they will rarely start conflicts, they are the last to back down. Fire Elementalists, fueled by passion and prowess, wield both martial arts and elemental fire in a harmonious dance of destruction and creation. Their training encompasses the mastery of weapons, shields, and close combat. Many who leave their conclaves embark on the path of the soldier, mercenary, or adventurer, seeking wisdom and growth through the heat of battle. They inspire greatness in allies and are the most charismatic of all the elementalists. Water Elementalists, rare and nearly lost, have experienced a resurgence as the ancient art of healing and restoration is rediscovered. These wise scholars and empathetic healers possess an unparalleled understanding of life energy, allowing them to mend wounds and protect themselves from harm. They often serve as healers, physicians, counselors, and sages, sharing their wisdom and serenity with those in need. Their patience is formidable, but when pushed to the limit, their wrath is as powerful as a raging ocean. Each elementalist path reflects the unique teachings and focus of their respective masters, who guide their apprentices in the ways of their chosen element. Despite their elemental differences, all elementalists share a profound sense of unity and respect for one another. As the world faces the dark threat of Bás and the Forces of Darkall, the elementalists of Tanares stands united.

trait.name: Creating an Elementalist
trait.text: When creating an elementalist, you must define how do you belong in Elementalism. What is your role? Which element represents you? Do you agree with its precepts? Are you an ally of a group or hermit elementalist? Why are you an adventurer? What do you seek in the world? After that, you must also define which characteristics (if any) from your element you carry in your behavior and personality. Are you a passional, fiery person, or are you stubborn like a rock? Or, even if you are connected to a certain element, is your personality more aligned to a different one? These questions define your character's goals, and how it will work to achieve them.

feature.name: Starting Elementalist
feature.text:
As a 1st-level Elementalist, you begin play with 6 + your Constitution modifier hit points.
You are proficient with the following items, in addition to any proficiencies provided by your race or background.
• Armor: None • Weapons: Clubs, daggers, quarterstaffs, shortbows, longbows • Tools: None • Saving Throws: Intelligence, Wisdom • Skills: Choose two from Arcana, History, Insight, Nature, Perception, Persuasion, and Religion
You begin play with the following equipment, in addition to any equipment provided by your background.
• (a) A quarterstaff or (b) a dagger or (c) a longsword and shield (only Primordial Element of Fire) • (a) a component pouch or (b) an elemental focus • (a) a diplomat's pack or (b) an explorer pack • A shortbow and 20 arrows.
If you forgo this starting equipment, as well as the items offered by your background, you start with 3d4 × 10 gp to buy your equipment.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 81 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Multiclass Elementalist
feature.text:
If your group uses the optional rule on multiclassing in the Player's Handbook, here's what you need to know if you choose elementalist as one of your classes.
Ability Score Minimum: As a multiclass character, you must have at least the following ability score(s) to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already an elementalist.
• Wisdom 13
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 274 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Multiclass Features
feature.text:
When you gain a new level in a class, you get its features for that level. You don't, however, receive the class's starting equipment, and a few features have additional rules when you're multiclassing: Channel Divinity, Extra Attack, Unarmored Defense, and Spellcasting.
Channel Divinity: If you already have the Channel Divinity feature and gain a level in a class that also grants the feature, you gain the Channel Divinity effects granted by that class, but getting the feature again doesn't give you an additional use of it. You gain additional uses only when you reach a class level that explicitly grants them to you. For example, if you are a cleric 6/paladin 4, you can use Channel Divinity twice between rests because you are high enough level in the cleric class to have more uses. Whenever you use the feature, you can choose any of the Channel Divinity effects available to you from your two classes.
Extra Attack: If you gain the Extra Attack class feature from more than one class, the features don't add together. You can't make more than two attacks with this feature unless it says you do (as the fighter's version of Extra Attack does). Similarly, the warlock's eldritch invocation Thirsting Blade doesn't give you additional attacks if you also have Extra Attack.
Unarmored Defense: If you already have the Unarmored Defense feature, you can't gain it again from another class.
Spellcasting: Your capacity for spellcasting depends partly on your combined levels in all your spellcasting classes and partly on your individual levels in those classes. Once you have the Spellcasting feature from more than one class, use the rules below. If you multiclass but have the Spellcasting feature from only one class, you follow the rules as described in that class.
Spells Known and Prepared: You determine what spells you know and can prepare for each class individually, as if you were a single-classed member of that class. If you are a ranger 4/wizard 3, for example, you know three 1 st-level ranger spells based on your levels in the ranger class. As a 3rd-level wizard, you know three wizard cantrips, and your spellbook contains ten wizard spells, two of which (the two you gained when you reached 3rd level as a wizard) can be 2nd-level spells. If your Intelligence is 16, you can prepare six wizard spells from your spellbook. Each spell you know and prepare is associated with one of your classes, and you use the spell casting ability of that class when you cast the spell. Similarly, a spellcasting focus, such as a holy symbol, can be used only for the spells from the class associated with that focus. If a cantrip of yours increases in power at higher levels, the increase is based on your character level, not your level in a particular class.
Spell Slots: You determine your available spell slots by adding together all your levels in the bard, cleric, druid, sorcerer, and wizard classes, half your levels (rounded down) in the paladin and ranger classes, and a third of your fighter or rogue levels (rounded down) if you have the Eldritch Knight or the Arcane Trickster feature. Use this total to determine your spell slots by consulting the Multiclass Spellcaster table. If you have more than one spellcasting class, this table might give you spell slots of a level that is higher than the spells you know or can prepare. You can use those slots, but only to cast your lower-level spells. If a lower level spell that you cast, like burning hands, has an enhanced effect when cast using a higher-level slot, you can use the enhanced effect, even though you don't have any spells of that higher level. For example, if you are the aforementioned ranger 4/ wizard 3, you count as a 5th-level character when determining your spell slots: you have four 1st-level slots, three 2nd-level slots, and two 3rd-level slots. However, you don't know any 3rd-level spells, nor do you know any 2nd-level ranger spells. You can use the spell slots of those levels to cast the spells you do know-and potentially enhance their effects.
Pact Magic: If you have both the Spellcasting class feature and the Pact Magic class feature from the warlock class, you can use the spell slots you gain from the Pact Magic feature to cast spells you know or have prepared from classes with the Spellcasting class feature, and you can use the spell slots you gain from the Spellcasting class feature to cast warlock spells you know.
Source: Player's Handbook (2014) p. 164

feature.name: Primordial Element
feature.text:
Every elementalist has a primary element they are connected to. At 1st level, you must choose your Primordial Element from the following options: Air, Earth, Fire, and Water. Your Primordial Element determines which spells you have access to, your Primary Element, your Secondary Elements, your Opposing Element, and a variety of features at 6th level, 10th level, and 14th level. You have access to spells from your Primary Element, your Secondary Elements, and the fusion of the two, choosing spells from their respective lists, as explained below, but never from your Opposing Element or its fusions. To find out what your Secondary Elements and Opposing Element are, refer to the Primordial Element table.
Primordial Element Primary Element | Secondary Element | Opposite Element Air | Fire and Water | Earth Earth | Fire and Water | Air Fire | Air and Earth | Water Water | Air and Earth | Fire
For example: An elementalist who chooses Air can choose their spells from the Air, Fire, and Water spell lists, but can never choose spells from the Earth element, or use any Fusion Spells that include Earth.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 83 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Spellcasting
feature.text:
Your studies and practices of the elementalism teachings have granted you the ability to cast spells by channeling the power of the elemental planes through the force of will over the elements.
Cantrips. Starting at 1st level, you know 3 cantrips determined by your primary element. You also know the special cantrip elemental surge, which has characteristics determined by your primary element, as well as the essential cantrip of your primary element and one essential cantrip of one of your secondary elements.
Spell slots. The elementalist table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your elemental spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these elemental spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest. For example, if you know the 1st-level elemental spell air beneath your feet and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slots available, you can cast air beneath your feet using either slot.
Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher. You know two 1st-level spells of your primary element and two 1st-level spells of your secondary elements of your choice from the elemental spell list. You learn two spells of your primary element and two of your secondary elements every time you gain access to a new spell level. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 3rd level in this class, you can learn two new spells of 1st or 2nd level. You can never learn to cast spells of your opposite element. Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the elemental spells you know and replace it with another spell from the elemental spell list, which also must be of a level for which you have spell slots.
Spellcasting Ability. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your elementalist spells, since the power of your magic depends on your willpower over the elements. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an elementalist spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spellcasting Focus. You can use an elemental focus as a spellcasting focus for your elemental spells.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 83 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Elemental Flux
feature.text:
Starting at 1st level, when you cast an elemental spell, it generates a magical energy flow that allows you to enhance or modify your elemental surge cantrip. Each spell has in its description how to modify the elemental surge in the Elemental Flux field. This modification only applies to your next elemental surge cast and is lost if you finish a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 83 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Fusion Spells
feature.text:
Starting at 1st level, you know all the fusion spells related to your primary and secondary elements, and of the same spell levels your elementalist class level has given you access to (two fusion spells per spell level). However, you can only cast them in a specific way. These fusion spells do not count against the number of your known spells.
Fused Elements | Fusion element Air and Fire | Lightning Air and Water | Spirit Earth and Fire | Lava Earth and Water | Plant
Casting Fusion Spells: When you cast an elementalist spell of 1st level or higher, write down the spell's element. If the last two spells you cast have different elements, you can use a spell slot to cast a fusion spell that combines those two elements. When you do this, erase any previous spell notes. If you cast a spell that's not a fusion spell when you already have two spell notes, write down the new spell's element and keep only the last two spell notes, erasing the oldest one. Your spell notes disappear when you finish a short or long rest. For example, an elementalist casts accelerate and takes note that he has cast an air spell, then he casts burning eyes and takes note that he has cast a fire spell. When casting his next spell, he may choose to use any of his spell slots to cast a lightning fusion spell of whatever level he has access to, such as energize nerves. If he casts a lightning spell, he must erase all his notes, but if he casts earth armor, an earth elemental spell, he must take note of the earth element and can no longer cast a lightning spell, but now he can cast a lava spell.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 83 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Primordial Bond
feature.text:
At 2nd level, you gain the ability to cast an elemental spell from your primary element, regardless of whether it's part of your known spells or not, as an action and without using a spell slot. The level of the spell cast with this feature cannot exceed one-third of your elementalist level (rounded up). After using this feature, you must complete a long rest before you can use it again.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Ability Score Improvement
feature.text:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a feat.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.text:
Starting at 18th level, you no longer need to have cast an elemental spell before casting a fusion spell, and you don't need to keep track of the elements of the spells you cast.

feature.name: Elemental Pinnacle
feature.text:
At 20th level, for the next minute after casting a spell, you become immune to a type of damage based on the last spell you cast according to the next table.
Elemental Pinnacle: Element | Immunity Air or Lightning | Lightning Earth or Plant | Acid Fire or Lava | Fire Water or Spirit | Cold
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Primordial Element: Air Primordial Element
feature.text:
Elementalists connected to this Primordial Element are usually strongly linked to freedom, deception, mobility, and dexterity. By choosing Air as your Primordial Element you can learn Air, Water, and Fire spells, the latter two being your secondary elements, and you will know the fusion element spells of Lightning and Spirit.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Wind Wisdom (Air Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 1st level, the liberty and adaptability of the air bestow you with new skills. You gain proficiency with two skills of your choice from Acrobatics, Deception, Persuasion, and Stealth. Additionally, you gain the ability to use the Disengage and Hide actions as a bonus action, and reduce the height of any fall by 30 feet when calculating falling damage.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Swift and Graceful (Air Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 6th level, you gain proficiency in Dexterity saving throws, have advantage on initiative rolls, and your ranged spell attacks ignore half cover and three-quarter cover.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Soul of the Wind (Air Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 10th level, your bond with air allows you to fly. You gain a flying speed that equals your walking speed. Additionally, as a bonus action, you can become invisible for a minute or until you make an attack or cast a spell. You can use this ability once, regaining its use after a short or long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Air Body (Air Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 14th level, you can use your bonus action to channel the energy of air and become ethereal for 1 minute. This enables you to move through spaces occupied by obstructions and creatures without penalty, and move without provoking attacks of opportunity. For the duration, you also gain resistance to all non-magical bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, and immunity to the grappled condition. You cannot use this feature again until you complete a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 84 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Primordial Element: Earth Primordial Element
feature.text:
Elementalists who choose this Primordial Element are strongly linked to law, resolution, stability, and strength. By choosing Earth as your Primordial Element, you can learn Earth, Water, and Fire spells, with the latter two being your secondary elements, and you will know the fusion element spells of Lava and Plant.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 86 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Grounded Learnings (Earth Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 1st level, the endurance and stability of Earth grant you new abilities. You gain proficiency with two skills of your choice from Athletics, History, and Survival. Your hit point maximum increases by 1 at the first level, and by an additional 1 each time you gain an elementalist level. When not wearing any armor or shield, your Armor Class is determined as 10 + your Constitution modifier + your Wisdom modifier, replacing the usual Dexterity modifier.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 86 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Earth Sense (Earth Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 6th level, your bond with the earth allows you to sense its shapes and forms. You gain a tremorsense with a range of 30 feet. Aditionally, as a bonus action, you can emit a harmless shockwave, identifying all terrains, walls, doors, passages, objects, and creatures within a 90-foot radius and pinpointing their exact locations. This ability can be used a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus plus your Wisdom modifier, regaining all when you finish after a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 86 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Earth Shield (Earth Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 10th level, if you are not surprised, you can take a reaction to form a rock shield in response to an attack or a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution saving throw. This stone shield provides a bonus to your AC and saves equal to your Wisdom modifier, lasting until the start of your next turn. This ability can be used twice, regaining all uses when you finish a short or long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 86 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Tomb of Invulnerability (Earth Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 14th level, when targeted or affected by an attack, spell, or any effect except divine intervention, you can use your reaction to manifest an invincible stone tomb for protection. Weighing 12,000 pounds, this tomb is impervious to all but divine intervention. Inside the tomb, you are immune to all damage and any physical, mental, or magical effects. However, you also become incapacitated, unable to perform actions, reactions, bonus actions, speak, or issue mental commands. No communication can penetrate the tomb, but you retain your tremorsense, with its range extended to 120 feet within the tomb. You can choose to end this effect at the start of each turn, causing the tomb to dematerialize instantly. Any effects or conditions affecting you prior to entering the tomb are suspended while inside, nullifying their effects but also halting their duration. Inside the tomb, you are unaffected by hunger, thirst, and don't need to breathe, but you continue aging normally. It is not possible to take rests within the tomb. This feature can't be used again until you complete a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 86 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Primordial Element: Fire Primordial Element
feature.text:
Elementalists who choose this Primordial Element are strongly linked to battles, creativity, destruction, and intelligence. By choosing Fire as your Primordial Element, you can learn Fire, Air, and Earth spells, the latter two being your secondary elements, and you will know the fusion element spells of Lava and Lightning.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Flame Brilliance (Fire Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 1st level, the creativity and cunning of fire afford you new abilities. You gain proficiency with two skills of your choice from Intimidation, Investigation, and Performance. You also gain proficiency with light armor, shields, and simple weapons. You can cast your elementalist spells even when your hands are holding weapons or shields, performing the necessary gestures to cast them. When wielding a weapon, your melee weapon attack rolls can use your Wisdom modifier instead of Strength or Dexterity. This modifier also applies to damage rolls from the 6th level.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Fiery Reprisal (Fire Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 6th level, when you are the target of an attack, you can take a reaction to make a melee weapon attack against an enemy within range.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Burning Inspiration (Fire Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 10th level, you can use your connection with Fire to inspire your allies. As a bonus action, you can imbue yourself and all allies within 30 feet of you with the power of flames, granting them an extra 1d6 fire damage to all unarmed, weapon, or spell attacks. This effect lasts for 1 minute. After using this ability, you can't use it again until you complete a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Second Surge (Fire Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 14th level, when using a spell slot to augment your elemental surge cantrip, you can use this cantrip again on the next turn, as an action, as if you had spent a spell slot one level lower.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Primordial Element: Water Primordial Element
feature.text:
Elementalists who choose this Primordial Element are strongly attached to peace, tradition, restoration, and wisdom. By choosing water as your Primordial Element you can learn Water, Air and Earth spells, the latter two being your secondary elements, and you will know the fusion element spells of Plant and Spirit.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Water Teachings (Water Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 1st level, the tradition and wisdom of water enable you to gain new abilities. You gain proficiency with two skills of your choice from Medicine, Nature, and Religion. Additionally, each time you cast an elementalist spell that heals a creature, you can also heal another creature up to 60 feet away, provided it was not healed by the original spell. The creature healed through this trait regains 1d6 hit points per level of the spell used.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Flowing Water (Water Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 6th level, your understanding of the life-sustaining flow of water allows you to adapt to adversity. While conscious and not wearing armor or wielding a shield, your Wisdom modifier is added to all saving throws you make, in addition to any other applicable modifiers.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Purifying Rain (Water Primordial Element)
feature.text:
Starting at 10th level, as a bonus action, you can call forth a 30-foot radius rainstorm at a point up to 240 feet away, lasting for 1 minute. Upon activating this ability, you and your allies within the area recover 2d8 hit points each, and any conditions, diseases, or curses affecting them are removed. For the duration, you and your allies in the area have advantage on all saving throws. This ability has no effect on undead and constructs. After using this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)

feature.name: Healing Tide (Water Primordial Element)
feature.text:
At 14th level, you can unleash the healing powers of water in a surge of vitality. As a bonus action, you create a 60-foot emanation around you that lasts for 1 minute. During this time, you and all creatures who finish their turn within the area recover hit points equal to your elementalist level. Additionally, any healing spells cast on a creature within the area recover extra hit points equal to your elementalist level. This ability has no effect on undead and constructs. After using this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.
Source: Player's Guide to Tanares p. 87 (Homebrew)
